Initial data has pointed out a special vulnerability of elderly people. Case 41 series have identified age as an independent prognostic factor for mortality 3 . 42 Also, national registries have shown a high mortality rate among patients over 43 80 years old 4-6 . Therefore, elderly people seem to have a higher proportion of 44 severe cases of COVID-19 and fatal outcome. The present study aims to 45 analyze the available data of mortality in the elderly population compared to 46 its younger counterparts. 47 48 49

The metanalysis of currently available national and regional reports of Since the start of the pandemic, age has been outlined as key prognosis 108 determinant in Covid-19 patients. Based on the early statistical data of China, 109 the case-fatality rate (CRF) increases markedly from the age of 60, reaching 110 14.8% in those over 80 14 . Initial data from Italian patients also described that 111 mortality increased significantly in septuagenarian patients and almost tripled 112 in octogenarians 15 . In a Chinese cohort study, age was identified as an 113 independent predictor of mortality, with an Odds Ratio = 1.1 (95% CI 1.03-114 1.17) for each year 3 . Our analysis of 611,583 patients shows a mortality 115 increase related to age; this is evident in patients ≥60 years, increasing 116 significantly in each decade of life. Therefore, the highest mortality occurs in 117 the patients ≥80 in whom it was 6-times higher than in younger patients. 118

These findings are consistent with a higher susceptibility to the infection 119 and severe clinical manifestations observed in elderly of patients 3, 16 . This fact 120 could be influenced by both the physiological aging process and, especially, 121 the greater prevalence in elderly patients of frailty and comorbidities that 122 contribute to a decrease in functional reserve that reduces intrinsic capacity 123 and resilience and hinders the fight against infections 17

The metanalysis of currently available data suggest a determinant effect 142 of age in mortality of Covid-19 patients with a relevant threshold on age >50 143 and especially >60. Nevertheless, more clinical and basic research is needed 144 to elucidate the mechanism involved in the COVID-19 infection in elderly 145 patients and to develop strategies to improve outcomes in these patients.
